question: Question 1 Two coins are tossed simultaneously. The probability (upto two decimal points accuracy) of getting at least one head is _______
solution: Total four possibilities {HH. HT, TH, TT} The probability of getting at least one head is [latex]\frac{3}{4}[/latex].

question: Question 2 The divergence of the vector -yi+xj______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \vec { F } & = - y \bar { i } + x \bar { j } \\ \nabla \cdot \bar { F } & = \frac { \partial } { \partial x } ( - y ) + \frac { \partial } { \partial y } ( x ) \\ & = 0 + 0 = 0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 3 The determinant of a 2x2 matrix is 50. If one eigenvalue of the matrix is 10, the other eigenvalue is _____.
solution: The product of eigen value of always equal to the determinant value of the matrix. [latex] \begin{aligned} \lambda_{1} &=10 \quad \lambda_{2}=\text { unknown } \quad|A|=50 \\ \lambda_{1} \cdot \lambda_{2} &=50 \\ 10\left(\lambda_{2}\right) &=50\\ \therefore \qquad \lambda_{2}&=5 \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 4 A sample of 15 data is follows: 17, 18, 17, 17, 13, 18, 5, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 20, 17, 3. The mode of the data is
solution:
Mode means highest number of observations 
or occurrence of data most of the time as data 
17, occurs four times, i.e., highest time. So 
mode is 17.

question: Question 5 The Laplace transform of [latex]te^{t}[/latex]  is
solution: [latex]f ( t ) = t e ^ { t } [/latex] [latex] L ( t ) = \frac { 1 } { s ^ { 2 } } [/latex] By first shifting rule [latex] L\left( t e ^ { t } \right) = \frac { 1 } { ( s - 1 ) ^ { 2 } }[/latex]

question:
Question 6 A mass m is attached to two identical springs having spring constant k as shown in the figure. The natural frequency [latex]\omega[/latex]
 of this single degree of freedom system is
solution: Equivalent stiffness [latex] k_{e q}=k+k=2 k[/latex] Natural frequency is [latex] \omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{k_{\mathrm{eq}}}{m}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \mathrm{k}}{\mathrm{m}}}[/latex]

question: Question 7 The state of stress at a point is [latex]\sigma _{x}=\sigma _{y}=\sigma _{z}=t_{xz}=t_{zx}=t_{yz}=t_{zy}=0[/latex] and [latex]t_{xy}=t_{yx}=50MPa[/latex] . The maximum normal stress (in MPa) at that point is_____.
solution: Given state of stress condition indicates pure shear state of stress. For pure shear state of stress, Max. tensile stress = Max. comp. stress = Max. Shear stress [latex] =\tau_{X Y}=50 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex] Hence, Max. normal stress [latex] =50 \mathrm{MPa} [/latex]

question: Question 8 For a loaded cantilever beam of uniform cross-section, the bending moment (in N.mm) along the length is [latex]M(x)=5x^{2}+10x[/latex] , where x is the distance (in mm) measured from the free end of the beam. The magnitude of shear force (in N) in the cross-section at x=10 mm is
solution: [latex](\mathrm{BM})_{x-x}=M_{x-x}=5 x^{2}+10 x[/latex] [latex] \text { (S.F) }_{x-x}=F_{x-x}=?[/latex] We know that at section X-X [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{X-X} &=\frac{d}{d x}\left[5 x^{2}+10 x\right] \\ F_{X-X} &=10 x+10 \\ \left(F_{X-X}\right)_{x=10 \mathrm{mm}} &=10(10)+10=110 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 9 A cantilever beam of length L and flexural modulus EI is subjected to a point load P at the free end. The elastic strain energy stored in the beam due to bending (neglecting transverse shear) is
solution: Let U is the S.E. in the beam due to B.M.  (M) [latex]U=\int_{0}^{L}\frac{(M_{x-x})^2 dx}{2(EI)_{x-x}}=\int_{0}^{L}\frac{(Px)^2 dx}{2EI_{NA}} [/latex] [latex]U=\frac{P^2}{2EI_{NA}}\int_{0}^{L}x^2dx=\frac{P^2}{2EI}\left ( \frac{L^3}{3} \right ) [/latex] [latex]U=\frac{P^2L^3}{6EI_{NA}}[/latex]

question: Question 10 A steel bar is held by two fixed supports as shown in the figure and is subjected to an increases of temperature [latex]\Delta T=100^{\circ}C[/latex].If the coefficent of thermal exapnasion and young's  modules of elasticity of steel  are [latex]11\, \times \, 10^{-6} \, /^{\circ}C[/latex] and 200GPa, respectively, the magnitude of thermal stress (in MPa) induced in the bar is _____
solution: We know that for completely restricted expansion, thermal stress developed in bar is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{t h} &=\alpha(\Delta T) E \\ &=11 \times 10^{-6} \times 100 \times 200 \times 10^{3}\\ &=220 \mathrm{MPa}\text{(comp. in native)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 11 A machine component made of a ductile material is subjected to a variable loading with [latex]\sigma _{min}=-50[/latex] MPa and [latex]\sigma _{max}=50[/latex] MPa .If the corrected endurance limit and the yield strength for the material are [latex]\sigma\, '_{e}=100[/latex]  MPa  and   [latex]\sigma_{y}=300[/latex]  MPa , the factor of safety is _______
solution: Given variable loading is a completely reversed  fatigue or variable loading because [latex] \begin{array}{c} \sigma_{\max }=-\sigma_{\min } \\ \text { Hence, } \sigma_{\text {mean }}=\sigma_{m}=0 ; \sigma_{\text {variable }}=\sigma_{v}=\sigma_{\max } \end{array}[/latex] For completely reversed fatigue loading  Soderberg, Goodman, Gerber and strength criterion will give same results. As per strength criterion, [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{\max } & \leq \sigma_{\text {per }} \text { or } \frac{\text { failure stress }}{\text { F.O.S. }} \\ \sigma_{\max } &=\frac{\text { Endurance limit }}{N} \\ N &=\frac{\text { Endurance limit }}{\text { Max. stress }}=\frac{100}{50}=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 12 In a slider-crank mechanism, the lengths of the crank and the connecting rod are 100mm and 160mm, respectively. The crank is rotating with an angular of 10 radian/s counter-clockwise. The magnitude of linear velocity (in m/s) of the piston at the instant corresponding to the configuration shown in the figure is_____.
solution: After plotting I-centres Here, [latex]I_{23}[/latex] and [latex]I_{24}[/latex] will come at same point Applying angular Velocity Theorem at [latex]I_{24} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \omega_{2}\left(I_{24} I_{12}\right) &=V_{4}=V_{B} \\ V_{B} &=\omega_{2}\left(I_{24} I_{12}\right)=10 \times 0.1 \\ \left(I_{24} I_{12}=100 \mathrm{mm}\right.&=0.1 \mathrm{m}=A B) \\ V_{B} &=1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 13 Which one of the following statement is TRUE?
solution: Pelton [latex]\rightarrow[/latex]  Impulse turbine Francis [latex]\rightarrow[/latex]  Radial in and Axial out (i.e Impulse and Raction partly) Kalpan [latex]\rightarrow[/latex]  Axial rotate out (i.e Pure Reaction)

options.A: Both Pelton and Francis turbines are impulse turbines.
options.B: Francis turbine is a reaction turbine but Kaplan turbine is an impulse turbine.
options.C: Francis turbine is an axial'flow reaction turbine.
options.D: Kaplan turbine is an axial'flow reaction turbine.

question: Question 14 A mass m of a perfect gas at pressure [latex]P_{1}[/latex]  and volume [latex]V_{1}[/latex]  undergoes an isothermal process. The final pressure is [latex]P_{2}[/latex]  and volume is [latex]V_{2}[/latex]. The work done on the system is considered positive. If R is the gas constant and T is the temperature, then the work done in the process is
solution: Work done on the system is considered as positive, so [latex] \delta W=-P d V[/latex] (-ve sign is taken as dV is-ve during compression) [latex] \begin{aligned} W &=-\int_{1}^{2} P d V=-\int_{1}^{2} m R T \frac{d V}{V} \\ &=-m R T \int_{1}^{2} \frac{d V}{V}=-m R T \ln \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \\ &=-m R T \ln \frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}=-P_{1} V_{1} \ln \frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 15 If a mass of moist air contained in a closed metallic vessel is heated, then its
Question 16 For the stability of a floating body the
solution: [latex]GM=BM-BG[/latex] (i) [latex]GM \gt 0[/latex], stable (ii) [latex]GM = 0[/latex], Neutral (iii) [latex]GM \gt 0[/latex], unstable NOTE:: Metacentre (M) must always be above the centre of gravity.

options.A: centre of buoyancy must coincide with the centre of gravity
options.B: centre of buoyancy must be above the centre of gravity
options.C: centre of gravity must be above the centre of buoyancy
options.D: metacenter must be above the centre of gravity

question: Question 17 Consider a laminar flow at zero incidence over a flat plate. The shear stress at the wall is denoted by [latex]t_{w}[/latex].  The axial positions [latex]x_1[/latex] and [latex]x_1[/latex] on the plate are measured from the leading edge in the direction of flow. If [latex]x_{2 \gt x_{1}}[/latex], then
solution:
Laminar flow over plate As per Blasius [latex] \begin{aligned} C_{l_{x}}&=\frac{0.664}{\sqrt{R_{e x}}}\\ 
 \text{and} \;  \quad C_{f x}&=\frac{\tau_{\omega}}{\frac{1}{2} \rho u_{\infty}^{2}} \\ \frac{0.664}{\sqrt{\frac{U_{\infty} x}{v}}}&=\frac{\tau_{\omega}}{\frac{1}{2} \rho u_{\infty}^{2}} \\ \tau_{\omega} &\propto \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}\\ \text{as }\quad x_{2}&  \gt x_{1} \\ \tau_{\omega 2}& \lt \tau_{\omega 1} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 18 The heat loss from a fin in 6W. The effectiveness and efficiency of the fin are 3 and 0.75, respectively. The heat loss (in W) from the fin, keeping the entire fin surface at base temperature, is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} q_{\text {actual }} \text { from fin } &=6 \text { watt } \\ \eta_{\text {fin }} &=\frac{q_{\text {actual }}}{q_{\text {max possible }}} \text { i.e. when entire } \end{aligned}[/latex] fin at base temperature [latex] \therefore [/latex]q from fin if entire fin at base temp [latex] =\frac{q_{\text {act }}}{0.75}=\frac{6}{0.75}=8 \text { watt }[/latex]

question: Question 19 The emissive power of a blackbody is P. If its absolute temperature is doubled, the emissive power becomes
solution: [latex]E_{b} \propto T^{4} [/latex](Stefan Boltzmann Law of Radiation) [latex] \frac{E_{b_{2}}}{E_{b_{1}}}=\left(\frac{2 T}{T}\right)^{4} \Rightarrow E_{b_{2}}=16 P[/latex]

question: Question 20 Which one of the following statements is TRUE for the ultrasonic machining (USM) process?
solution: Ultrasonic Machining uses an abrasive slurry which transfers the impact load provided by the vibrating tool to the work piece.

options.A: In USM, the tool vibrates at subsonic frequency.
options.B: USM does not employ magnetostrictive transducer.
options.C: USM is an excellent process for machining ductile materials.
options.D: USM often uses a slurry comprising abrasive-particles and water.

question: Question 21 The crystal structure of aluminium is
solution: Crystal Structure of materials FCC: Ni, Cu, Ag, Pt, Au, Pb, Al (soft) - BCC: V, Mo, Ta, W (hard material) - HCP: Mg, Zn [latex] \text{Cobalt }\quad \mathrm{HCP}<420^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, \mathrm{FCC}>420^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex] [latex] \text{Chromium }\quad \mathrm{HCP}<20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, \mathrm{BCC}>20^{\circ} \mathrm{C} [/latex] Glass: Amorphous BCC: Ferrite or [latex]\alpha-\text{iron}\;\; \delta-\text{ferrite}\; \text{or } \;\delta -\text{iron}[/latex] FCC: Austenite or [latex]\gamma-\text{iron}[/latex]

question: Question 22 Given the atomic weight of Fe is 56 and that of C is 12, the weight percentage of carbon in cementite [latex](\textrm{Fe}_{3}C)[/latex]  is ________
solution: [latex]\frac{12}{56 \times 3+12 \times 1} \times 100 \%=6.67 \%[/latex]

question: Question 23 For a single with Poisson arrival and exponential service time, the arrival rate is 12 per hour. Which one of the following service rates will provide a steady state finite queue length?
solution:
For steady state, [latex]
\mu>\lambda[/latex] as  [latex]\lambda=12\text{cust/hr}[/latex], we should go with option (D) 24/hr

question: Question 24 The standard deviation of linear dimensions P and Q are 3 m and 4 m, respectively. When assembled, the standard deviation (in m) of the resulting linear dimension (P+Q) is ________
solution: According to Root Sum Square or RSS model [latex] \sigma_{a}=\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sigma_{i}^{2}}[/latex] where, [latex] \sigma_{a}= [/latex] assembly tolerance standard deviation [latex] \sigma_{i}=i^{\text {th }} [/latex] component tolerance standard deviation Here [latex] \sigma_{P}=3 \mu \mathrm{m} [/latex] and [latex] \sigma_{Q}=4 \mu \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] \sigma_{a}=\sqrt{\sigma_{P}^{2}+\sigma_{Q}^{2}}=\sqrt{3^{2}+4^{2}}=5 \mu \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 25 It is desired to make a product having T-shaped cross-section from a rectangular aluminium block. Which one of the following processes is expected to provide the highest strength of the product?
solution: In metal forming there will be increased mechanical properties due to change in grain size and work hardening.

question: Question 26 The surface integral  [latex]\int \underset{s}{\int} F. n dS[/latex] over the surface S of the sphere [latex]x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=9[/latex], where [latex]F=(x+y)i+(x+z)j+(y+z)k[/latex] and n is the unit outward surface normal, yields ______.
solution: [latex]\quad F = ( x + y ) i + ( x + z ) j + ( y + z ) k [/latex] [latex] \nabla \cdot F = \frac { \partial } { \partial x } ( x + y ) + \frac { \partial } { \partial y } ( x + z ) + \frac { \partial } { \partial z } ( y + z ) [/latex] [latex] = 1 + 0 + 1 = 2 [/latex] By Gauss divergence theorem [latex] { l } \iint _ { s } F \cdot \hat { n } d S = \iint _ { V } \nabla \cdot \bar { F } d V = \iint _ { V } 2 d V [/latex] [latex] = 2 V \text { where } V \text { is volume of } x ^ { 2 } + y ^ { 2 } + z ^ { 2 } [/latex] [latex] = 2 \left( \frac { 4 } { 3 } \pi ( 3 ) ^ { 3 } \right) = 226.08[/latex]

question: Question 27 Consider the differential equation [latex]3y{}''(x)+27y(x)=0[/latex]  with initial conditions [latex]y(0)=0[/latex] and [latex]y{}'(0)=2000[/latex]. The value of y at x=1 is ____.
solution: The direction is [latex]3 y^{\prime \prime}(x)+27 y(x)=0 [/latex] The auxillary equation is [latex] \begin{aligned} 3 m^{2}+27 &=0 \\ m^{2}+9 &=0 \\ m &=\pm 31 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \text{Solution is} y=c_{1} \cos 3 x+c_{2} \sin 3 x [/latex] [latex] \text{given that} y(0)=0 [/latex] [latex] \therefore 0=c_{1} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} y^{\prime} &=-3 c_{1} \sin 3 x+3 c_{2} \cos 3 x \\ y^{\prime}(0) &=2000 \\ 2000 &=0+3 c_{2} \\ c_{2} &=\frac{2000}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Solution is [latex] y=\frac{2000}{3} \sin 3 x[/latex] [latex] \text{when }x=1 \quad y=\frac{2000}{3} \sin 3=94.08[/latex]

question: Question 28 Consider the matrix [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 50 & 70\\ 70 & 80 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]  whose eigenvectors  corresponding to eigenvalues [latex]\lambda _{1}[/latex] and [latex]\lambda _{2}[/latex] are [latex]X_{1}=\begin{bmatrix} 70\\ \lambda _{1}-50 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] and [latex]X_{2}=\begin{bmatrix} \lambda _{2}-80\\ 70 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] ,  respectively. The value of [latex]X_{1}^{T} X_{2}[/latex]  is _____.
solution: [latex]A=\left[\begin{array}{ll}50 & 70 \\70 & 80\end{array}\right][/latex] Eigen values of A are [latex]\lambda_{1}, \lambda_{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2} &=130 \\ \lambda_{1} \lambda_{2} &=-900 \\ &\text { Given that } \\ X_{1} &=\left[\begin{array}{c}70 \\\lambda_{1}-50\end{array}\right] \\ X_{2}&=\left[\begin{array}{c}\lambda_{2}-80 \\70\end{array}\right] \\ X_{1}^{T} X_{2} &=\left[70 \quad \lambda_{1}-50\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}\lambda_{2}-80 \\70\end{array}\right] \\ &=70 \lambda_{2}-5600+70 \lambda_{1}-3500 \\ &=70\left(\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2}\right)-9100 \\ &=70(130)-9100 \\ &=9100-9100=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 29 If [latex]f(z)=(x^{2}+ay^{2})+ibxy[/latex]  is a complex analytic function of [latex]z=x+iy[/latex] ,where [latex]i=\sqrt{-1}[/latex], then
solution: Given that the analytic function [latex] \begin{aligned} f(2) &=\left(x^{2}+a y^{2}\right)+i b x y \\ u+i v &=\left(x^{2}+a y^{2}\right)+i(b x y) \\ u &=x^{2}+a y^{2} ; \quad v=b x y \\ u_{x} &=2 x ; \quad u_{y}=2 a y \\ v_{x} &=b y ; \quad v_{y}=b x \\ u_{x} &=v_{y} ; \quad u_{y}=-v_{x} \\ 2 x &=b x ; \quad 2 a y=-b y \\ b &=2 ; \quad 2 a=-b \quad \text { since } b=2 \\ 2 a &=-2 \\ a &=-1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 30 Block 2 slides outward on link 1 at a uniform velocity of 6 m/s as shown in the figure. Link 1 is rotating at a constant angular velocity of 20 radians/s counterclockwise. The magnitude of the total acceleration [latex](in\, m/s^{2})[/latex] of point P of the block with respect to fixed point O is ___.
solution: [latex] \begin{array}{l} V=6 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \omega=20 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{array}[/latex] Here the centripital and corialis acceleration will be there Total Acceleration: [latex] \begin{aligned} a_{p} &=\sqrt{(40)^{2}+(240)^{2}} \\ &=243.310 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 The radius of gyration of a compound pendulum about the point of suspension is 100mm. The distance between the point of suspension and the centre of mass is 250mm. Considering the acceleration due to gravity as [latex](9.81\, m/s^{2})[/latex], the natural frequency (in radian/s) of the compound pendulum is ______.
solution: If we displace this by an angle [latex]\theta[/latex] clockwise: [latex]I \ddot{\theta}+m g \cdot a \sin \theta=0[/latex] Taking [latex]\theta [/latex] very small: [latex] \begin{array}{c} \sin \theta \approx \theta \qquad(k=100 \mathrm{mm}=0.1 \mathrm{m}) \\ \mathrm{r} \ddot{\theta}+\mathrm{mg} \cdot \mathrm{a} \cdot \theta=0 \\ \ddot{\theta}+\left(\frac{\mathrm{mg}}{\mathrm{I}} \mathrm{a}\right) \theta=0 \\ \mathrm{Here} \quad I=m \mathrm{k}^{2}=\mathrm{m}(0.1)^{2} \end{array}[/latex] (I is the MI about the point of Hinge) [latex] \begin{array}{l}\qquad\begin{aligned} I&=m(0.01) \mathrm{kg}-\mathrm{m}^{2} \\ a&=250 \mathrm{mm}=0.250 \mathrm{m} \\ g&=9.81 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \end{aligned}\\ \ddot{\theta}+\left(\frac{m \times 9.81 \times 0.250}{(0.01) m}\right) \theta=0 \\ \ddot{\theta}+(245.25) \theta=0 \\ \qquad \omega_{n}=\sqrt{245.25}=15.660 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 32 A gear train shown in the figure consists of gear P, Q, R and S. Gear Q and gear R are mounted on the same shaft. All the gears are mounted on parallel shafts and the number of teeth of P, Q, R and S are 24, 45, 30 and 80, respectively. Gear P is rotating at 400 rpm. The speed (in rpm) of the gear S is _____
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{ll} T_{P}=24 \\ T_{Q}=45 & N_{P}=400 \mathrm{rpm} \\ T_{R}=30 & N_{S}=? \\ T_{S}=80 \end{array}[/latex] [latex] Here gear R is not meshing at all. [latex] \begin{array}{l} \frac{N_{P}}{N_{Q}}=\frac{T_{O}}{T_{P}}=\frac{45}{24} \qquad \cdots(1)\\ \frac{N_{Q}}{N_{S}}=\frac{T_{S}}{T_{Q}}=\frac{80}{45}\qquad \cdots(2)\\ \text{By }(1) \times(2) \\ \frac{N_{P}}{N_{S}}=\frac{45}{24} \times \frac{80}{45} \\ N_{S}=N_{P} \times \frac{24}{80}=\frac{400 \times 24}{80} \\ N_{S}=120 \text { r.p.m } \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 33 A helical compression spring made of wire of circular cross-section is subjected to a compressive load. The maximum shear stress induced in the cross-section of the wire is 24 MPA. For the same compressive load, if both the wire diameter and the mean coil diameter are doubled, the maximum shear stress (in MPa) induced in the cross-section of the wire is _______
solution: Max. shear stress induced in spring wire of a helical compression spring is given by, [latex] \begin{array}{c} \tau_{\max }=\frac{8 W D}{\pi d^{2}} k_{W} \quad \text { or } \quad \frac{8 W C}{\pi d^{2}} k_{W} \\ \tau_{\max } \propto \frac{1}{d^{2}} \\ {\left[\because W_{1}=W_{2}=W ; C_{1}=C_{2}\left(\text { i.e., } C=\frac{D}{d}\right)\right.} \\ \left.\left(k_{W}\right)_{1}=\left(k_{W}\right)_{2}=k_{W}\right] \\ \frac{\tau_{2}}{\tau_{1}}=\left(\frac{d_{1}}{d_{2}}\right)^{2} \\ \frac{\tau_{2}}{24}=\left(\frac{d}{2 d}\right)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \tau_{2}=6 \mathrm{MPa} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 34 Three masses are connected to a rotating shaft supported on bearings A and B as shown in the figure. The system is in a space where the gravitational effect is absent. Neglect the mass of shaft and rods connecting the masses.for [latex]m_{1}=10[/latex] kg,[latex]m_{2}=5[/latex] kg and [latex]m_{3}=2.5[/latex] kg and for a shaft angular speed of 1000 radian/s, the magnitude of the bearing reaction (in N) at location B is_____
solution: It means all three masses are in same plane let us calculates the net force [latex] \begin{array}{c} \Sigma F_{x}= \Sigma \mathrm{m} \mathrm{r} \omega^{2} \cos \theta \\ =\left(10 \times 0.1 \times \omega^{2}\right)-\left(5 \times 0.2 \times 6^{2} \cos 60^{\circ}\right) \\ -\left(2.5 \times 0.4 \times \omega^{2} \cos 60^{\circ}\right) \\ =\left[1-\left(5 \times 0.2 \times \frac{1}{2}\right)-\left(2.5 \times 0.4 \times \frac{1}{2}\right)\right] \omega^{2}=0 \\ \Sigma F_{y}= \Sigma \mathrm{mr} \omega^{2} \sin \theta \\ =\left(5 \times 0.2 \times \omega^{2} \sin 60^{\circ}\right) \\ -\left(2.5 \times 0.4 \times \omega^{2} \sin 60^{\circ}\right) \\ =\left[\left(1 \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)-\left(1 \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)\right] \omega^{2} \\ =\left[\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)\right] \omega^{2}=0 \end{array}[/latex] Net force, [latex] =\sqrt{\Sigma F_{x}^{2}+\Sigma F_{y}^{2}}=0[/latex] Therefore reaction at B is zero. [latex] R_{B}=0[/latex]

question: Question 35 A steel plate, connected to a fixed channel using three identical bolts A, B and D, carries a load of 6kN as shown in the figure. Considering the effect of direct load of moment, the magnitude of resultant shear force (in kN) on bolt C is.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{P}&=\frac{P}{n}=\frac{P}{3}=2 \mathrm{kN} \\ r_{A}&=r_{C}=50 ;\left(P_{S}\right)_{A}=\left(P_{S}\right)_{C} \\ r_{B}&=0 \Rightarrow\left(P_{S}\right)_{B}=0 \\ \frac{\left(P_{S}\right)_{C}}{r_{C}}\left[r_{C}^{2}+r_{B}^{2}+r_{A}^{2}\right]&=P \times e \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \left(P_{S}\right)_{C} \times 2 \times r_{C}=P \times e [/latex] [latex] \left(P_{S}\right)_{C}=\frac{6 \times 250}{2 \times 50}=15 \mathrm{kN} [/latex] [latex] \theta_{A}=180^{\circ} ; \theta_{C}=0^{\circ} [/latex] Resultant shear force [latex] \left(R_{C}\right)=P_{P}+\left(P_{S}\right)_{C} [/latex] [latex][\therefore \theta_{C}=0^{0}] [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{C}&=2+15=17 \mathrm{kN} \\ R_{A}&=\left(P_{S}\right) A-P_{P}=13 \mathrm{kN} \\ R_{B}&=P_{P}=2 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 A single - plate clutch has a friction disc with inner and outer radii of 20 mm and 40 mm, respectively. The friction lining in the disc is made in such a way that the coefficient of friction [latex]\mu[/latex]  varies radially as [latex]\mu=0.01r[/latex], where r is in mm. The clutch needs to transmit a friction torque of 18.8 [latex]kN\! \! \cdot\! mm[/latex]. As per uniform pressure theory, the pressure (in MPa) on the disc is ________
solution: Normal load on elemental ring [latex](d M)=p 2 \pi r d r [/latex] Frictional force on elemental ring [latex]\left(d F_{f}\right)=\mu d W [/latex] Frictional torque transmitted by elemental ring, [latex] d T_{f}=\left(d F_{f}\right) r[/latex] Hence, [latex] \quad d T_{f}=\mu p 2 \pi r^{2} d r [/latex] Total frictional torque transmitted by clutch plate [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(T_{f}\right)&=\int_{R_{i}}^{R_{0}} d T_{f} \\ T_{f}&=\int_{R_{i}}^{P_{0}} \mu p 2 \pi r^{2} d r\\ \text{As per U.P.T.}\\ T_{f} &=2 \pi p \int_{R_{i}}^{R_{0}} \mu r^{2} d r \\ T_{f} &=2 \pi p \int_{R_{i}}^{R_{0}}(0.01 r) r^{2} d r \\ \left(T_{f}\right)_{U . P . T .} &=(2 \pi p)(0.01)\left[\frac{R_{0}^{4}-R_{i}^{4}}{4}\right] \\ 18.85 \times 10^{3} &=2 \pi p(0.01)\left[\frac{40^{4}-20^{4}}{4}\right] \\ p &=0.5 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 37 The principal stresses at a point in a critical section of a machine component are [latex]\sigma _{1}=60[/latex] MPa, [latex]\sigma _{2}=5[/latex] MPa and [latex]\sigma _{2}=-40[/latex] MPa. For the material of the component, the tensile yield strength is [latex]\sigma _{y}=200[/latex] MPa. According to the maximum shear stress theory, the factor of safety is
solution: As per max. shear stress theory, safe condition for design, [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Absolute } \tau_{\max }&=\frac{S_{Y S}}{N} \text { or } \frac{S_{Y_{t}}}{2 N}\\ \text{Absolute }\tau_{\max }&= \text{larger of}\\ &\begin{array}{l} {\left[\left|\frac{\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}}{2}\right|,\left|\frac{\sigma_{2}-\sigma_{3}}{2}\right|,\left|\frac{\sigma_{3}-\sigma_{1}}{2}\right|\right]} \\ =\left|\frac{\sigma_{3}-\sigma_{1}}{2}\right| \end{array}\\ &\left[\because \sigma_{1} \text { and } \sigma_{3} \text { are unlike in nature }\right] \\ &=\left|\frac{-40-60}{2}\right|=50 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \text{Hence,}\quad50&=\frac{200}{2(N)}\\ N&=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 38 The rod PQ of length [latex]L=\sqrt{2}[/latex] m,and uniformly distributed mass of M=10 kg, is released from rest at the position shown in the figure. The ends slide along the frictionless faces OP and OQ. Assume acceleration due to gravity, [latex]g=10 \:m/s^{2}[/latex].  The mass moment of inertia of the rod about its centre of mass and an axis perpendicular to the plane of the figure is [latex](ML^{2}/12)[/latex]. At this instant, the magnitude of angular acceleration (in radian/[latex]s^{2}[/latex] ) of the rod is _____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L&=\sqrt{2} m \\ M&=10 \mathrm{kg}\\ g&=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Both the surfaces are smooth [latex] \begin{aligned} \ddot{\theta} &=\alpha=\frac{3 g}{2 L} \sin \theta \\ \alpha &=\frac{3 \times 10}{2 \times \sqrt{2}} \sin 45^{\circ} \quad\left[\because \theta=45^{\circ}\right] \\ a &=\frac{3 \times 10}{2 \times \sqrt{2}} \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=\frac{30}{4} \\ &=7.5 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 39 The arrangement shown in the figure measures the velocity V of a gas of density [latex]1\, kg/m^{3}[/latex] flowing through a pipe. The acceleration due to gravity is [latex]9.81\, m/s^{2}[/latex].If the manometric fluid is water (density 1000 kg/[latex]s^{2}[/latex]) and the velocity V is 20 m/s, the differential head h (in mm) between the two arms of the manometer is _____
solution: Method: (i) Given data: [latex] p_{\text {gas }}=1 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} ; \quad g=9.81 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} [/latex] [latex] \rho_{m}=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}, \quad V=20 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} [/latex] Dynamic pressure of gas [latex] =(\rho g h)_{\text {water }} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} \rho_{\mathrm{gas}} V^{2} &=\rho_{m} \times 9.81 \times h \\ \frac{1}{2} \times 1 \times(20)^{2} &=1000 \times 9.81 \times h\\ \text{or }h &=0.02038 \mathrm{m} \text { of water } \\ &=20.38 \mathrm{mm} \text { of water } \end{aligned}[/latex] Method: (ii) [latex] \begin{aligned} \rho_{m} &=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}, \rho_{w}=1 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ V &=20 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ V &=\sqrt{2 g h\left(\frac{\rho_{m}}{\rho_{w}}-1\right)} \\ 20 &=\sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times h\left(\frac{1000}{1}-1\right)} \\ h &=20.40 \mathrm{mm} \text { of water } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 40 A 60 mm-diameter water jet strikes a plate containing a hole of 40 mm diameter as shown in the figure. Part of the jet passes through the hole horizontally, and the remaining is deflected vertically. The density of water is 1000 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]. If velocities are as indicated in the figure, the magnitude of horizontal force (in N) required to hold the plate is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \rho&=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \text{Force, F}&= \text{momentum }_{\text {inlet }}- \text{ momentum }_{\text {outlet }} \\ F &=(\dot{m} v)_{i n}-(\dot{m} v)_{o u t} \\ F &=\rho\left[\frac{\pi}{4}\left(D_{1}^{2}-D_{2}^{2}\right)\right] \times V^{2} \\ &=1000 \frac{\pi}{4} \times\left[0.06^{2}-0.04^{2}\right] \times 20^{2} \\ &=628.32 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 For the laminar flow of water over a sphere, the drag [latex]C_{F}[/latex]  is defined as [latex]C_{F}=F/(pU^{2}D^{2})[/latex], where F is drag force,[latex]\rho[/latex] is the fluid density, U is the fluid velocity  and D is the diameter of the sphere. The density of water is 1000 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]. When the diameter of the sphere is 100mm and the fluid velocity is 2m/s, the drag coefficient is 0.5. If water now flows over another sphere of diameter 200mm under dynamically similar conditions, the drag force (in N) on this sphere is_____
solution: Drag coefficient: [latex] C_{F}=\frac{F}{\rho U^{2} D^{2}}[/latex] or Drag force: [latex] F=C_{F} \rho U^{2} D^{2}[/latex] Given data for sphere- -1 [latex] \begin{aligned} \rho_{1}&=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ D_{1}&=100 \mathrm{mm}=0.1 \mathrm{m} \\ U_{1}&=2 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ C_{F}&=0.5 \end{aligned}[/latex] For sphere- 2 [latex] \begin{aligned} \rho_{2}&=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ D_{2}&=200 \mathrm{mm}=0.2 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] For dynamically similar conditions, [latex] \begin{aligned} (\mathrm{Re})_{1}&=(\mathrm{Re})_{2}\\ \frac{U_{1} D_{1}}{v_{1}}&=\frac{U_{2} D_{2}}{v_{2}}\\ \text{or }\qquad U_{1} D_{1} &=U_{2} D_{2} \quad \therefore v_{1}=v_{2} \\ 2 \times 0.1 &=U_{2} \times 0.2\\ \text{or }\qquad U_{2}&=1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\\ F_{2} &=C_{F} \rho U_{2}^{2} D_{2}^{2} \\ &=0.5 \times 1000 \times(1)^{2} \times(0.2)^{2} \\ &=20 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 42 In the Rankine cycle for a steam power plant the turbine entry and exit enthalpies are 2803 kJ/kg and 1800 kJ/kg, respectively. The enthalpies of water at pump entry and exit are 121 kJ/kg and 124 kJ/kg, respectively. The specific steam consumption (in kg/k W.h) of the cycle is _______
solution: Given data [latex]h_{1}=2803\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} h_{2} &=1800 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{3} &=121 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{4} &=124 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ w_{T} &=h_{1}-h_{2} \\ &=2803-1800=1003 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ w_{P} &=h_{4}-h_{3} \\ &=124-121=3 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ w_{\text {net }} &=w_{T}-w_{P}=1003-3 \\ &=1000 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \mathrm{SSC} &=\frac{3600}{W_{\text {net }}}=\frac{3600}{1000}=3.6 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{kWh} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 43 A calorically perfect gas (specific heat at constant pressure 1000 J/[latex]kg\cdot K[/latex] ) enters and leaves a gas turbine with the same velocity. The temperatures of the gas at turbine entry and exit are 1100 K and 400 K, respectively. The power produced is 4.6 MW and heat escapes at the rate of 300 kJ/s through the turbine casing. The mass flow rate of the gas (in kg/s) through the turbine is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} c_{p}&1\mathrm{kJ}/\mathrm{kg-K}\\ V_{i}&=V_{e}(\text { Inlet and exit velocity same }) \\ \dot{W}_{C . V} &=4.6 \mathrm{MW}=4.6 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{kW} \\ \dot{Q} &=300 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying SFEE, [latex] \begin{aligned} \dot{m}(h_{i}+\frac{1}{2} V_{i}^{2}+g z_{i})+ \dot{Q} &=\dot{m}(h_{e}+\frac{1}{2} V_{e}^{2}+g z_{e})+\dot{W}_{C . V} \\ \dot{m}[c_{p}(T_{i}-T_{e})]+\dot{Q}&=\dot{W}_{C . V} \quad \text { (Let } z_{i}=z_{e}) \\ \dot{m}[1 \times(1100-400)]+(-300)&=4.6 \times 10^{3} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \dot{m}&=7 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 44 One kg of an ideal gas (gas constant R=287 J/kg.K) undergoes an irreversible process from state-1 (1 bar,300K) to state -2 (2 bar, 300 K). The change in specific entropy ([latex]s_{2}-s_{1}[/latex]) of the gas (in J/[latex]kg\cdot K[/latex]) in the process is ______
solution: Change in specific entropy of ideal gas [latex] \begin{aligned} S_{f}-s_{i} &=c_{p} \ln \frac{T_{f}}{T_{i}}-R \ln \frac{P_{f}}{P_{i}} \\ &=1005 \ln \frac{300}{300}-287 \ln \frac{2}{1} \\ &=0-287 \ln 2=-198.93 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kg}^{-k} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 45 The volume and temperature of air (assumed to be an ideal gas) in a closed vessel is 2.87 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]  and 300K, respectively. The gauge pressure indicated by a manometer fitted to the wall of the vessel is 0.5bar. If the gas constant of air is [latex]R=287\, J/kg\! \cdot \! K[/latex]  and the atmospheric pressure is 1 bar, the mass of air (in kg) in the vessel is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{g}&=5 \mathrm{bar}=50 \mathrm{kPa} \\ R&=287 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK}=0.287 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}^{\mathrm{K}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Ideas gas equation: [latex] P V=m R T[/latex] Here P is absolute pressure: [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=P_{a b s}=P_{\text {gauge }}+P_{\text {atm }} \\ &=50+101.325=151.325 \mathrm{kPa} \\ m &=\frac{P V}{R T}=\frac{151.325 \times 2.87}{0.287 \times 300}=5.04 \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 In a counter-flow heat exchanger, water is heated at the rate of 1.5kg/s from [latex]40\,^{\circ} C[/latex]  to [latex]80\,^{\circ} C[/latex] by an oil entering at [latex]120\,^{\circ} C[/latex] and leaving at [latex]60\,^{\circ} C[/latex].  The specific heat of water and oil are [latex]4.2\:kJ/kg \! \cdot\!K[/latex]  and [latex]2\:kJ/kg \! \cdot\!K[/latex], respectively. The overall heat transfer coefficient is [latex]400\, W/m^{2} \cdot K[/latex]  The required heat transfer surface area (in [latex]m^{2}[/latex] ) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta T_{i} &=120-80=40^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ \Delta T_{e} &=60-40=20^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ (L M T D) \text { Counterflow }&=\frac{\Delta T_{i}-\Delta T_{e}}{\ln \frac{\Delta T_{i}}{\Delta T_{e}}} =28.86^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ &=\frac{40-20}{\ln \frac{40}{20}} = 28.86^{o}\mathrm{C}\\ Q &=\dot{m}_{C} c_{p_{c}}\left(T_{c e}-T_{c i}\right) \\ &=1.5 \times 4.2 \times 10^{3}(80-40) \mathrm{watt} \\ Q &=252000 \mathrm{W} \\ Q &=U A \Delta T_{m} \\ A &=\frac{Q}{U \Delta T_{m}}=\frac{1.5 \times 4.2 \times 10^{3} \times 40}{400 \times 28.86} \\ &=21.83 \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 47 A metal ball of diameter 60mm is initially at [latex]220\, ^{\circ}C[/latex]. The ball is suddenly cooled by an air jet of [latex]20\, ^{\circ}C[/latex]. The heat transfer coeffient is [latex]200 \: W/m^{2}[/latex]. The specific heat,thermal  conductivity and density of the metall ball are [latex]400\:J/kg\! \cdot\! K[/latex] ,[latex]400\:W/m\! \cdot\! K[/latex]  and [latex]9000\,kg/m^{3}[/latex], The ball temperature (in [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]) after 90 seconds will be approximately.
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} c_{p} &=400 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ k &=400 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{mK} \\ \rho &=9000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \text { Time }(\tau) &=90 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex] since K being high and size of ball being small, lumped heat analysis is valid. [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad e^{\left(\frac{h A}{\rho V C_{p}}\right)^{\tau}}&=\frac{T_{i}-T_{\infty}}{T-T_{\infty}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad\left(\frac{h_{A}}{\rho v c_{p}}\right) \tau&=\ln \left(\frac{T_{i}-T_{\infty}}{T-T \infty}\right) \\ \text{Put }\quad \frac{A}{V}&=\frac{3}{R}=\frac{3}{\left(\frac{30}{1000}\right)} \\ \left(\frac{h A}{\rho v c_{p}}\right) \tau &=\left(200 \times \frac{3}{0.03} \times \frac{1}{9000} \times \frac{1}{400}\right) \times 90 \\ &=0.5 \\ \frac{220-20}{T-20} &=e^{0.5}=1.6487 \\ T &=141.3^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 48 A product made in two factories P and Q, is transport to two destinations, R and S. The per unit costs of transportation (in Rupees) from factories to destinations are as per the following matrix: Factory P produces 7 units and factory Q produces 9 units of the product. Each destination required 8 units. If the north-west corner method provides the total transportation cost as X (in Rupees) and the optimized (the minimum) total transportation cost Y (in Rupees), then (X-Y), in Rupees, is
solution: As per GATE official answer key MTA (Marks to All) X=105 Using penalty corner method and following modi method we get -4 water value indicates that its optimum table, so [latex] \begin{aligned} Y &=7 \times 7+3 \times 8+4 \\ &=49+24+4=78 \\ X-Y &=105-77=28 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 49 A project starts with activity A and ends with activity F. The precedence relation and durations of the activities are as per the following table: The minimum project completion time (in days) is _______.
solution: There are two path, [latex] \begin{aligned} A-B-D-F=30 \text { days } \\ A-C-E-F=24 \text { days } \end{aligned}[/latex] Critical path A-B-D-F and of 30 days and it is also minimum time required to complete project.

question: Question 50 A rod of length 20mm is stretched to make a rod of length 40 mm. Subsequently, it is compressed to make a rod of final length 10 mm. Consider the longitudinal tensile strain as positive and compressive strain as negative. The total true longitudinal strain in the rod is_______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \varepsilon_{E} &=\frac{4-L_{0}}{L_{0}}=\frac{10-20}{20}=-0.5 \\ \varepsilon_{T} &=\ln \left[1+\varepsilon_{E}\right]=\ln [1-0.5] \\ &=-0.693 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 Maximize [latex]Z=5x_{1}+3x_{2}[/latex], subject to [latex]x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 10[/latex] , [latex]x_{1}-x_{2}\leq 8[/latex] , [latex]x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0[/latex] , In the starting Simplex tableau, [latex]x_{1}[/latex] and [latex]x_{2}[/latex] are non-basic variables and the value of Z is zero. The value of Z in the next Simplex tableau is____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \operatorname{Max} . Z &=5 x_{1}+3 x_{2}+0 \times S_{1}+0 \times S_{2} \\ x_{1}+2 x_{1}+S_{1} &=10 \\ x_{1}-x_{2}+S_{2} &=8 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 52 A strip of 120 mm width and 8 mm thickness is rolled between two 300 mm-diameter rolls to get a strip of 120 mm width and 7.2 mm thickness. The speed of the strip at the exit is 30 m/min. There is no front or back tension. Assuming uniform roll pressure of 200 MPa in the roll bite and 100% mechanical efficiency, the minimum total power (in kW) required to drive the two roll is _______.
solution: Method-1: Projected length, [latex] \begin{aligned} L_{p} &=R \sin \alpha \approx \sqrt{R \Delta h} \\ &=\sqrt{150 \times(8-7.2)}=10.954 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Projected Area, [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{p} &=L_{p} \times b=10.954 \times 120 \\ &=1314.48 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Roll Separating Force, [latex] \begin{aligned} F &=\sigma_{0} \times L_{p} \times b N \\ &=200 \times 1314.48 \mathrm{N}=262.9 \mathrm{kN}\\ &\left[\sigma_{o} \text { in } N / m m^{2} \text { i.e. } M P a\right] \\ \text{ Arm length (a in mm)}&=0.5 L_{p} \text{for hot rolling}\\ &=0.5 \times 10.954 \mathrm{mm}=5.477 \mathrm{mm}\\ &=0.45 L_{p} \;\text{for cold rolling }\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Torque per roller, [latex] \begin{aligned} T &=F \times \frac{a}{1000} \mathrm{Nm} \\ &=262.9 \mathrm{kN} \times 5.477 \mathrm{mm} \\ &=1439.9 \mathrm{Nm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Total power for two roller, [latex] P=2 T \omega \text { in } W=2 T \times \frac{2 \pi N}{60}[/latex] For the calculation of N we need velocity of  neutral plane Continuity equation [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{0} b_{0} v_{0} &=h_{f} b_{f} v_{f} \\ 8 \times 120 \times v_{0} &=7.2 \times 120 \times 30 \\ \text{or}\quad v_{0} &=27 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} \end{aligned}[/latex] Assuming velocity of neutral plane average velocity, [latex] \begin{aligned} V &=\frac{V_{0}+V_{f}}{2}=\frac{27+30}{2} \\ &=28.5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min}\\ \text{Now,}V&=\pi D N\\ \text{or}\quad 28.5&=\pi \times 0.300 \times N\\ \text{or}\quad N&=30.24 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]  Total power for two roller, [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=2 T \times \frac{2 \pi N}{60} \\ &=2 \times 1439.9 \times \frac{2 \times \pi \times 30.24}{60} \mathrm{W} \\ &=9.1195 \mathrm{kW} \approx 9.12 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex] Method-II : Velocity at the neutral plane =? [latex] \begin{aligned} H_{n} V_{n}&=H_{2} V_{2} \quad(\text { Applying continuity }) \\ H_{n}&=H_{2}+0.25 \Delta H\\ &\text{(Standard relation)}\\ &=7.2+0.25 \times 0.8=7.4 \mathrm{mm} \\ V_{n}&=\frac{\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{V}_{2}}{\mathrm{H}_{n}}=29.19 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} \\ N&=\frac{29.19 \times 1000}{\pi \times 300}=30.98 \mathrm{rpm}\\ \text{total power }&=2 T \omega \\ &=2 \times 1439.9 \times 2 \pi \frac{30.98}{60} \\ &=9.34 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 A cylindrical pin of [latex]25_{+0.020}^{+0.010}\,mm[/latex]  diameter is electroplated. Plating thickness is [latex]2.0^{\pm 0.005}[/latex] mm.Neglecting the gauge tolerance, the diameter (in mm, up to 3 decimal points accuracy) of the GO ring gauge to inspect the plated pin is _______
solution: GO ring gauge will inspect maximum metal conditions i.e. UL of shaft i.e. Largest size after platting. UL after platting [latex] =25.02+2.005+2.005 \mathrm{mm}=  29.030 \mathrm{mm} [/latex]

question: Question 54 During the turning of a 20mm-diameter steel bar at a spindle speed of 400 rpm, a tool life of 20 minute is obtained. When the same bar is turned at 200 rpm, the tool life become 60 minute. Assume that Taylor's tool life equation is valid. When the bar is turned at 300 rpm, the tool lidfe (in minute) is approximately.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{1}=\pi D \times 400 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} ; & T_{1}=20 \mathrm{min} \\ V_{2}=\pi D \times 200 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} ; & T_{2}=60 \mathrm{min} \end{aligned}[/latex] Now using Taylor's equation [latex] \begin{array}{l} \qquad V_{1} T_{1}^{n}=V_{2} T_{2}^{n} \\ \text { or } \pi D \times 400 \times(20)^{n}=\pi D \times 200 \times 60^{\text {n }} \\ \text { or } \quad n=0.6309\\ \text { and } \quad V_{3}=\pi D \times 300 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} ; \quad T_{3}=?\\ \qquad V_{1} T_{1}^{n}=V_{2} T_{2}^{n}=V_{3} T_{3}^{n} \\ \pi D \times 400 \times(20)^{0.6309}=\pi D \times 300 \times T_{3}^{0.6309} \\ \therefore \quad T_{3}=31.55 \mathrm{min} \approx 32 \mathrm{min} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 55 In an orthogonal machining with a tool of [latex]9^{\circ}[/latex] orthogonal rake angle, the uncut chip thickness is 0.2mm. The chip thickness fluctuates between 0.25 mm and 0.4 mm. The ratio of the maximum shear angel to the minimum shear angle during machining is _________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given} \quad\alpha &=9^{\circ} \\ t &=0.2 \mathrm{mm} \\ t_{c \max } &=0.4 \mathrm{mm} \\ t_{c \min } &=0.25 \mathrm{mm} \\ \tan \phi_{\max } &=\frac{r_{\max } \cos \alpha}{1-r_{\max } \sin \alpha}=\frac{\frac{0.2}{0.25} \cos 9^{\circ}}{1-\frac{0.2}{0.25} \sin 9}\\ \text{or }\quad \phi_{\max } &=42.09^{\circ} \\ \tan \phi_{\min } &=\frac{r_{\min } \cos \alpha}{1-r_{\min } \sin \alpha}=\frac{\frac{0.2}{0.4} \cos 9^{\circ}}{1-\frac{0.2}{0.4} \sin 9^{\circ}}\\ \text{or}\quad \phi_{\mathrm{min}} &=28.18^{\circ} \\ \text { Ratio } &=\frac{\phi_{\max }}{\phi_{\min }}=\frac{42.09}{28.18}=1.494 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 56 The ways in which this game can be played _________ potentially infinite.
Question 57 If you choose plan P, you will have to _________ plan Q, as these two are mutually ________.
Question 58 If [latex]a \text{ and } b[/latex] are integers and [latex]a-b[/latex] is even, which of the following must always be even?
Question 59 A couple has 2 children. The probability that both children are boys if the older one is a boy is
Question 60 P  looks at Q while Q looks at R. P is married, R is not. The number of pairs of people in which a married person is looking at an unmarried person is

Question 61 "If you are looking for a history of India, or for an account of the rise and fall of the British Raj, or for the reason of the cleaving of the subcontinent into two mutually antagonistic parts and the effects this mutilation will have in the respective sections, and ultimately on Asia, you will not find it in these pages; for though I have spent lifetime in the country, I lived too near the seat of events, and was too intimately associated with the actors, to get the perspective needed for the impartial recording of these matters." Which of the following is closest in meaning to 'cleaving' ?

Question 62 X  bullocks and Y tractors take 8 days to plough a field. If we have the number of bullocks and double the number of tractors, it takes 5 days to plough the same field. How many days will it take X bullocks alone to plough the field?

Question 63 There are 4 women P, Q, R, S and 5 men V, W, X, Y, Z in a group. We are required to form pairs each consisting of one woman and one man. P is not to be paired with Z, and Y must necessarily be paired with someone. In how many ways can 4 such pairs be formed?

Question 64 All people in a certain island are either 'Knights' or 'Knaves' and each person knows every other person's identity. Knights never lie, and Knaves ALWAYS lie. P says "Both of us are Knights". Q says "None of us are Knaves". Which one of the following can be logically inferred from the above?

options.A: Both P and Q are knights.
options.B: P is a knight; Q is a Knave.
options.C: Both P and Q are Knaves.
options.D: The identities of P, Q cannot be determined.

question: Question 65 In the graph below, the concentration of a particular pollutant in a lake is plotted over (alternate) days of a month in winter (average temperature 10[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]) and a month in summer (average temperature 30[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]). Consider the following statements based on the data shown above: i.  Over the given months, the difference between the maximum and the minimum pollutant concentrations is the same in both winter and summer ii.  There are atleast four days in the summer month such that the pollutant concentrations on those days are within 1 ppm of the pollutant concentrations on the corresponding days in the winter month. Which one of the following options is correct?
